IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 9103 S1381-1169(14)00200-3 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.05.003 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 pH value of the precursor slurry during ageing. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the AT_X precursors after variable ageing time. Fig. 3 DTG/MS curves of the CuZnAl precursors. Fig. 4 SEM images of the CuZnAl precursors before and after calcination at 300°C. Fig. 5 TPR profiles of the CuZnAl oxide forms. Fig. 6 The effect of precursor ageing time on active copper surface area of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 7 The correlation between the copper surface area and the HT-CO3 2− content in precursors after various ageing time. Fig. 8 The effect of the precursor ageing time on the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst activity in LT-WGS. Fig. 9 The effect of the precursor ageing time on TOF of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst in LT-WGS. Table 1 The comparison of the physicochemical properties of precursors, oxide forms and reduced catalysts after various ageing time of the precursor. Sample pH of precursor slurry Precursor Total CO2 (Nml/g) HT-CO3 2− share (%) AT_0 7.3 36.1 70.1 AT_1 7.8 37.7 67.8 AT_2 8.9 39.6 64.8 AT_4 9.3 40.4 64.4 AT_10 10.0 38.4 59.2 AT_24 9.5 35.4 57.6 HT-CO3 2− (%) – ratio of the HT-carbonates to the total amount of carbonates in a precursor. Sample Oxide form Reduced form S BET (m2/g) Temp. of max. reduction rate (°C) S Cu (m2/gCu) D Cu (%) 1st band 2nd band AT_0C 42.4 208 264 25.9 4.0 AT_1C 41.2 202 267 27.3 4.2 AT_2C 38.7 191 274 24.0 3.7 AT_4C 36.2 186 275 23.1 3.6 AT_10C 36.8 183 270 22.3 3.4 AT_24C 46.0 205 270 18.6 2.9 Table 3 The rate constants and TOF for catalysts with different precursor ageing time. Sample WGS rate constant k (Ndm3 g−1 h−1 ata−0.4) TOF (s−1) 220°C 200°C 220°C 200°C AT_0C 20.44 8.67 0.046 0.022 AT_1C 20.16 8.48 0.043 0.022 AT_2C 18.0 6.39 0.053 0.027 AT_4C 15.0 4.63 0.049 0.016 AT_10C 12.82 4.32 0.046 0.016 AT_24C 15.17 5.07 0.054 0.023 The effect of the precursor ageing on properties of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for low temperature water–gas shift (LT-WGS) Paweł Kowalik ⁎ Marcin Konkol Katarzyna Antoniak Wiesław Próchniak Paweł Wiercioch Fertilizer Research Institute, Al. Tysiąclecia Państwa Polskiego 13A, 24-110 Puławy, Poland Fertilizer Research Institute Al. Tysiąclecia Państwa Polskiego 13A Puławy 24-110 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +48 814731441. Graphical abstract The effect of the precursor ageing time on the structure, thermal decomposition, specific surface area, active copper surface area as well as on the morphology of the precursors and catalysts oxide forms was investigated. The hydroxycarbonate precursor, with the composition corresponding to industrial catalysts, was prepared via coprecipitation method from the solutions of copper and zinc nitrate with a mixture of sodium aluminate and sodium carbonate at pH=7.4 and then aged in the mother liquor. The activity of the prepared catalysts in the LT-WGS reaction was compared under conditions similar to those in the industrial process. The results reveal that the precursor ageing influences the precursor phase composition, the active copper surface area and the catalytic activity. The activity decreases with the increasing ageing period but the activity concerned a single surface copper atom (TOF) is constant and independent of the ageing time. Keywords Water–gas shift Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst Coprecipitation Ageing time 1 Introduction The Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts have found many applications in the C1 chemistry, most of all in methanol synthesis and processing as well as in the low temperature water–gas shift reaction (LT-WGS) [1], according to Eq. (1) below: (1) CO+H2O↔CO2 +H2 ΔH 298K =−41kJ/mol The Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts applied in the industry are mainly the ones with a high CuO content (50–70wt.%) [2], obtained from hydroxycarbonate precursors. The preparation of the catalytic materials on the industrial scale is generally carried out via precipitation of the precursor from the solution of appropriate metal salts with the solution of sodium carbonate and/or hydroxide or sodium aluminate [3], followed by the thermal treatment and forming [4]. Other techniques of the precursor preparation are also known such as sol-gel method [5], microemulsion technique [6] or homogeneous precipitation by urea route [7]. However, there is a general agreement that the coprecipitation in the presence of carbonates leads to the formation of the best materials, i.e. the hydroxycarbonates precursors, which in the course of further processing give the Cu/ZnO systems with high active copper surface area. There is also a consensus on the fact that the Cu/ZnO catalyst activity is proportional to the copper active surface area [8] and reaction is structure insensitive [9]. The nature of the active site is complex, with reduced copper and to some extent also ZnO being involved in the formation of the active site [10,11]. The total Cu/ZnO interfacial area and Cu dispersion can be correlated with a content of high-temperature carbonates (HT-CO3 2−) in a precursor [12,13]. It is known that in case of the Cu/ZnO catalysts the structural interactions among precursor components influence the resulting catalytic performance. This correlation is called “chemical memory”, in other words the catalytic material “remembers” its origin [14] and each preparation step determines the properties of the final catalyst. Therefore, the coprecipitation mode (batch or continuous) [12,15] and conditions (the stirring intensity [16–18], pH [19,20], temperature [21,22] and solvent additives [23]) are of high importance. During the coprecipitation process it is desirable to obtain a high homogeneity of the components and the appropriate phase composition of the precursor. Moreover, post-treatment steps, including ageing in mother liquor, also influence the properties of coprecipitated catalytic materials [24]. During the ageing process the final formation of the precursor structure and surface takes place. The studies reported by Behrens et al. [25] indicate the formation of the precursor mesostructure during ageing, whereas the thermal decomposition of the precursor to its oxide form is accompanied by the formation of the active phase microstructure. During ageing a series of parallel transformations takes place including nucleation, growth, phase transition and aggregation that were described in the literature [26–28]. It appears that the phase transformations during ageing are dissolution–renucleation processes. They result in growing of the initially amorphous nanograins into the larger particles and the final formation of crystals and agglomerates. Recrystallization between crystalline phases can also occur. The literature data analysis reveals that the pH changes during ageing play a key role in the formation of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 precursor properties. As a result of the gradual CO2 evolution from the precursor suspension, the pH value increases during ageing. However, the observations of many researchers indicate that during the ageing process the pH-drop may occur that is accompanied by changes in colour of the precursor and phase transformations of the material [25,29,30]. The results of Jung et al. [31] lead to the conclusion that the pH increase during ageing results in the increase of specific surface area and active surface area as well as porosity and catalytic activity. The ageing time longer than 36h is not advantageous, because it results in the distinct deterioration of the abovementioned parameters. This effect can be levelled via maintenance of a constant pH value by bubbling the precursor slurry e.g. with CO2 during ageing. The studies reported by Bems et al. [13] also show that the maintenance of the constant pH is advantageous and the resulting catalytic material is fine-grained with the phase composition being different from that of the precursor aged at decreasing pH. Due to the lack of appropriate research techniques, which could give insight into the course of these processes in real conditions, in-depth description of mechanisms driving these changes is difficult. For this reason, the efforts to investigate are limited primarily to the evaluation of the effects of the ageing time and conditions on the physicochemical properties and catalytic activity. Despite the fact that the ageing process influences the catalytic materials properties, this parameter is often omitted at all in the experimental data on the preparation of precursors and catalysts. The literature data analysis of the binary Cu/ZnO or ternary Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 precursors indicates some arbitrariness in the approach to this issue, and the differences in the ageing time of the precipitated precursors reported by researchers may be quite substantial. Examples of the ageing time reported in the literature are: 30min [13], 30–120min [32], 12h [33] or 72h [31]. The results reported by Bems et al. on the CuZnAl materials precipitated with NaHCO3 and Na2CO3 at pH≈7 at room temperature indicate that the ageing leads to the decrease of copper surface area. For this reason, the authors postulate to minimize the ageing time. In contrast, different conclusions can be drawn from the studies reported by Behrens [25] on binary CuZn systems, precipitated with sodium carbonate. In this case the specific surface area of the materials after ageing for 30 and 80min was, respectively, 32 and 57m2/g. Almost two-fold increase within only 50min may indicate a strong beneficial effect of ageing. It becomes therefore evident that the literature data on the effect of ageing time of the Cu/ZnO or Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 precursors concern the catalytic materials obtained by often different methods (co-precipitation at constant or decreasing/increasing pH, diluted or concentrated solutions) under different conditions (differences in temperature, stirring of reagents, etc.). Thus, comparing the physicochemical properties of the materials obtained is difficult or even impossible. In light of the above, it seems reasonable to systematize the knowledge about the impact of the conditions and ageing time on the parameters of copper-rich catalysts. The following contribution is an attempt to describe the impact of the ageing time of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst precursor (with the composition corresponding to the industrial catalysts), precipitated from concentrated solutions of copper and zinc nitrate with a mixture of sodium aluminate and sodium carbonate, on a number of physicochemical properties such as the structure and texture of materials, surface morphology, reducibility and the catalytic activity in the low temperature water–gas shift reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis A Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 precursor ((Cu+Zn)/Al=3.5 and Cu/Zn=2.3) was prepared by means of the coprecipitation method. The solutions of: (a) copper, zinc nitrates (Cu 1.9mol/l, Zn 0.93mol/l, acidified with HNO3 0.83mol/l), (b) sodium aluminate–carbonate (Al 0.73mol/l, NaOH 5.36mol/l, Na2CO3 1.1mol/l), (all reagents from POCh Gliwice, Poland) were slowly and simultaneously added to an HSW vessel with 2500ml of redistilled water heated up to 65±5°C and stirred (100rpm). The reaction temperature was maintained in a given range and the pH value of the resulting suspension was maintained in the range 7–7.4. After the addition was complete, a 100ml sample of the precursor slurry obtained was filtered off and the sodium and nitrate ions were thoroughly removed by washing out with redistilled water (to the conductivity of the filtrate below 100μS). The same procedure was carried out after 1, 2, 4, 10 and 24h of the precursor ageing under given conditions. The precursor samples after various ageing time were dried at 105°C for 20h, ground and sieved on a sieve with a mesh aperture of 0.1mm. The samples were denoted as AT_X, where X corresponds to the ageing time in hours. The precursors were further calcined at 300°C for 4h. The catalysts oxide forms were denoted as AT_XC. 2.2 Characterization The chemical composition of the catalysts was determined by means of the XRF method using a X’UNIQUE II Philips spectrometer. The XRD measurements of the precursors were performed on a PANalytical Empyrean system (Bragg-Brentano geometry) equipped with a PIXcel3D detector, using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.542Å) and operating at 40kV and 40mA. The samples were scanned between 10<2θ <70°, with the step size 0.053° and time/step of 20 or 30s. The SEM measurements were performed with a FEI Quanta3D FEG microscope using an electron beam with an energy of 5kV. The thermal decomposition studies were carried out using a Netzsch STA 449 Jupiter thermal analyzer coupled with a QMS 430C Aëolos mass spectrometer. The measurements were performed in a helium stream, elevating the sample temperature to 700°C with a rate of 10°C/min. The changes of the sample weight and m/z signals (m/z =18 and m/z =44) during the measurement were constantly monitored and on that basis the amount of evolved CO2 was calculated. The specific surface area (S BET) of the samples was determined by measuring nitrogen adsorption at the temperature of liquid nitrogen and p/p 0 =0.05–0.3 using a Micromeritics ASAP® 2050 Xtended Pressure sorption analyzer. The TPR analysis was performed using a Micromeritics AutoChem 2950HP instrument (5vol.% H2/Ar mixture, temperature increased to 400°C with a rate of 5°C/min.). The active copper surface area (S Cu) and its dispersion (D Cu) of the precursors calcined at 300°C and reduced in 5vol.% H2/Ar mixture at 250°C/4h was measured using the N2O chemisorption at 20°C – impulse technique [34–36]. The number of Cu surface atoms was calculated assuming surface oxide stoichiometry Cu/O=2 and density of surface copper atoms: 1.46×1019 at/m2. The methodology of the activity measurements in the LT-WGS reaction was described elsewhere [37]. The turnover frequencies (TOF) were calculated on the basis of the LT-WGS rate divided by the number of the exposed Cu surface atoms. 3 Results and discussion The pH changes of the mother liquor during ageing are shown in Fig. 1 . In the initial period (for ca. 8h) the pH value increased constantly from 7.4 to above 10. It was then slowly decreasing, reaching 9.5 after 24h of ageing. No pH-drop was observed, however, the colour of the precursor slurry changed gradually but quite distinctly from greenish to blue. The XRF analysis of the AT_0 (oxide form) revealed the following composition (wt.%): CuO: 58.3, ZnO: 25.6, Al2O3: 16.0 and <20ppm Na. The XRD patterns of the AT_X precursors are shown in Fig. 2 . As can be observed in Fig. 2, the XRD patterns of the samples, for which the ageing time is shorter than 10h, are characterized by broad diffraction peaks, indicating a relatively low degree of crystallinity of the components. In the case of the starting precursor sample AT_0, obtained without ageing, the highest intensity diffraction peak is observed at 2θ =12.7° together with another reflection of low intensity around 2θ =25.5°. Based on the comparative analysis of the diffraction pattern of the sample AT_0 with the reference patterns in the ICDD PDF-4 2012 database, it cannot be unequivocally attributed to any of the crystallographic phases of copper/zinc/aluminium hydroxycarbonates. These two diffraction reflections were also observed on the XRD pattern of the ternary Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system by Atake et al. and the authors suggested the formation of highly extended layered structure [38]. Moreover, the researchers reported for both the binary and ternary systems the presence of other XRD transparent phases such as e.g. zincian georgeite that were identified on the basis of spectroscopic measurements [39,40]. An attempt to assign the observed diffraction pattern with the line of the highest intensity at 2θ =12.7° to the aurichalcite or CuZnAl hydrotalcite-like phases may be questionable. This is due to the fact that this diffraction peak is shifted by 0.3° towards the lower 2θ angles than the characteristic reflection of the aurichalcite phase, (Cu2Zn3)(CO3)2(OH)6 (13.0°) and also by about 0.9° towards the higher 2θ angles with respect to the diffraction peak characteristic of the hydrotalcite analogue, Cu x Zn6−x Al2(OH)16(CO3)·4H2O (11.7–11.9°) [41]. Furthermore, not all diffraction peaks characteristic of these two phases are present in the AT_0 sample. Atake et al. assigned the reflections at 2θ =12.7 and 25.5° to a precursor of aurichalcite of a low Zn/Cu atomic ratio, with possible replacement of some Cu sites with Al [38]. No phases of aluminium-only compounds could be identified in the crystallographic composition of the AT_0 precursor. However, due to the low match of the observed X-ray diffraction pattern to the reference patterns, the determination of the phase composition and dominant phases in the initial period of ageing is difficult and to a large extent speculative. The extension of the ageing period results in better formation of the aurichalcite phase (the most intensive diffraction peak shifts towards the higher 2θ values, 12.8° for AT_1) together with formation of the minor (Cu0.9Zn0.1)2(OH)2(CO3) (ICDD 1-79-7850) phase. However, with further prolongation of the ageing time shifting of the highest intensity diffraction peak towards lower 2θ values (12.6° after 10h and 11.9° after 24h) occurs, indicating the formation of the hydrotalcite-like phase, Cu x Zn6−x Al2(OH)16(CO3)·4H2O (e.g. ICDD 37-629) The presence of this phase is indicated by the characteristic peaks among others at 2θ =11.9 and 23.9°. Moreover, two other minor phases, (Cu0.9Zn0.1)2(OH)2(CO3) and CuO were also observed. It can be concluded from the XRD results that during the ageing process of the CuZnAl precursors essential changes in the phase composition and a gradual increase of the crystallinity occurs, especially between 10 and 24h of ageing. The initially formed phase is of the aurichalcite-type. No crystallographic phases of aluminium-only compounds were identified in the materials within the first 10h of ageing. However, a distortion of aurichalcite structure was reported, causing changes in the XRD pattern, as a result of the Al3+ incorporation during the coprecipitation from a solution containing Cu, Zn, Al nitrates, due to the higher charge of Al3+ ions compared to those of Cu2+ and Zn2+ [42]. The prolongation of the ageing time results in the recrystallization of the initial hydroxycarbonates and final formation of the CuZnAl hydrotalcite-type phase after 24h of ageing. The DTG profiles and the corresponding CO2 and H2O evolution curves are presented in Fig. 3 . The data demonstrate that the thermal decomposition of the AT_X precursors can be divided into 3 main steps: removal of moisture (up to 150°C), an intensive step with the evolution of H2O and relatively low amounts of CO2 (150–400°C) and processes in the temperature range 520–700°C accompanied by the vigorous evolution of CO2 only. The ageing time affects the course of the thermal decomposition primarily by increasing the intensity of the H2O evolution in the range 100–170°C and by changes in the carbonates decomposition in the range 520–600°C (HT-CO3 2−). The amount of CO2 evolved in this temperature range decreases with the increasing ageing time, thereby the HT-CO3 2− part decreases during the precursor ageing. The data presented in Fig. 3 indicate that the calcination at 300°C does not result in HT-CO3 2− decomposition, and according to Bems et al. [13] these materials can be classified as carbonate-modified mixed oxides. The course of thermal decomposition of the samples resembles the results reported by others for similar materials [43,44].Fig. 4A–C presents the SEM images of three selected CuZnAl precursors after various ageing time, whereas the images of the oxide forms (after calcination at 300°C) are shown in Fig. 4D–F. The images indicate that independently of the ageing time the materials are characterized by the similar surface morphology. In the case of all precursors investigated dominant are the platelet particles with a size of 100–150nm merged into random agglomerates. No significant changes in morphology are observed with the increasing ageing time. This indicates that the morphology is determined at the initial stage of the precursor ageing and is stable throughout this process. The thermal treatment of the precursors at 300°C does not influence the surface morphology. The carbonate-modified oxide forms of the catalysts retain the precursor structure, i.e. consist of agglomerates of platelet-like particles arranged in a chaotic manner with respect to each other. The thermal decomposition of precursors with the evolution of gaseous products does not destroy the platelet morphology. This observation finds the confirmation in the results reported by other authors [45]. The TPR results for the AT_XC materials are presented in Fig. 5 . For all samples under studies one can observe two different reduction bands in the temperature range 180–230°C and an intensive band in the range 230–290°C. Such a multi-step reduction course is typical for Cu-based catalysts and results from the presence of different CuO species [46]. The low temperature bands can be assigned to the Cu2+ →Cu+ reduction, whereas the higher temperature band to the Cu+ →Cu0 reduction. This indicates a two-step reduction process (Cu2+ →Cu+ →Cu0) [47,48], however, the correct quantitative evaluation of the corresponding Cu species during reduction is difficult due to poor peak separation. The TPR profile may be also obscured in the temperature range of residual carbonates decomposition (ca. 250–320°C) that are stable under mild calcination conditions [49]. The oxide form of the AT_0C catalyst, obtained from the precursor without ageing, is characterized by two reduction bands of similar intensity. What is remarkable in the case of other catalysts is a distinct shift of the first reduction band towards lower temperatures and the simultaneous increase of the intensity of the high-temperature reduction band. The increase of the secondary peak intensity with the increasing ageing time of hydroxycarbonate precursors may also indicate the formation of more stable Cu+ species, stronger interactions between a part of Cu species and ZnO [50] or presence of Cu+ ions located in the zinc oxide lattice [51]. Table 2 comprises the parameters of the oxide forms and active copper surface area after reduction. The specific surface area of the catalysts is in the range from ca. 35 to 45m2/g, and in the initial ageing period (up to 4h) a distinct decrease can be observed. Longer ageing time of the precursor leads to the renewed increase of the specific surface area of the oxide form.The effect of the precursor ageing time on the active copper surface area is illustrated in Fig. 6 . The results reveal that the prolongation of the ageing time substantially decreases the active copper surface area. The copper surface area and copper dispersion of the AT_24C catalyst is ca. 20% lower compared to the AT_0C catalyst, obtained from the precursor without ageing. As it is shown in Fig. 3, all the precursors, independently of the ageing time, contain a high content of high-temperature carbonates (HT-CO3 2−), which are thought to influence the stabilization of the exposed Cu [12,13]. Our results also indicate that there is a correlation between the HT-CO3 2− content in precursors precipitated with sodium aluminate–carbonate and the copper surface area in final catalysts (Fig. 7 ). The higher is the HT-CO3 2− content in precursors, the higher is the active copper surface area. As shown in Table 1 , the HT-CO3 2− content gradually decreases during ageing, therefore, prolongation of this process might be disadvantageous [31]. An effect of the ageing time on the catalyst activity in WGS process carried out under the pressure of 2.5MPa is shown in Fig. 8 and Table 3 . The data presented lead to the conclusion that the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst activity decreases with ageing time. The decline of the catalyst activity is the most significant (even more than 25% comparing to AT_0C) for relatively short ageing time. It implies that due to inordinate prolongation of the ageing process less active catalyst is obtained. The turnover frequencies (TOF) of AT_XC catalysts calculated from the WGS rate at 200 and 220°C and exposed Cu surface area are shown in Fig. 9 and Table 3. Despite the distinct influence of the ageing time on the catalytic activity per unit weight of catalyst, it can be seen that the TOF values for catalysts vary only slightly at given temperature. The average TOFs are 0.048 and 0.021 at 220 and 200°C, respectively. From the TOF comparison, it appears that, independently of the ageing time, the Cu atoms exposed on the surface can produce similar amount of hydrogen per active site. It is, therefore, justified to conclude that TOF is essentially constant. This may indicate that above all, the copper surface area influences the catalytic activity and the impact of ageing on changes in the properties of the active sites is negligible. Prolonged ageing time results in a decrease of the catalytic activity, mainly due to recrystallization of the precursor and formation of worse dispersed and less reducible copper active sites with similar activity per active site. 4 Conclusions The experimental data reveal a remarkable effect of the precursor ageing time on the physicochemical properties of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts. The ageing of precursor, precipitated with sodium aluminate–carbonate, is accompanied by slow and gradual recrystallization of the primary hydroxycarbonates initially of the aurichalcite-type into the finally hydrotalcite-like. Simultaneously, fluctuations of the precursor carbonization degree (CO2 content) occur, with a steadily decreasing share of high-temperature carbonates (HT-CO3 2−). The ageing process does not influence substantially the precursor morphology, and independently of the ageing time the dominant are platelet particles merged into random agglomerates. The longer is the precursor ageing time, the higher becomes a share of more difficult reducible oxide forms and the lower is copper dispersion in the catalytic material. The WGS reaction rate per site (TOF) is constant independently of the ageing time. Acknowledgements This article is created as part of project No. POKL.08.02.01-06-005/12 under the title “Building the science and engineering of INS through the implementation of technologies into industrial practice”, realized by Polish Foundation of the Opportunities Industrialization Centres “OIC Poland” in Lublin. coredata.dc:description: The effect of the precursor ageing time on the structure, thermal decomposition, specific surface area, active copper surface area as well as on the morphology of the precursors and catalysts oxide forms was investigated. The hydroxycarbonate precursor, with the composition corresponding to industrial catalysts, was prepared via coprecipitation method from the solutions of copper and zinc nitrate with a mixture of sodium aluminate and sodium carbonate at pH=7.4 and then aged in the mother liquor. The activity of the prepared catalysts in the LT-WGS reaction was compared under conditions similar to those in the industrial process. The results reveal that the precursor ageing influences the precursor phase composition, the active copper surface area and the catalytic activity. The activity decreases with the increasing ageing period but the activity concerned a single surface copper atom (TOF) is constant and independent of the ageing time.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of the precursor ageing on properties of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for low temperature water–gas shift (LT-WGS)
